questions.question: A current asset is one that is expected to be realized or consumed within:

options.A: Six months or the operating cycle, whichever is shorter
options.B: One year or the operating cycle, whichever is longer
options.C: One year regardless of operating cycle

questions.explanation: Current assets are expected to be realized within one year or the operating cycle, whichever is longer. For most companies, this is one year.
questions.tip: Current = 1 year or operating cycle, whichever is longer.

questions.question: Prepaid expenses are classified as:

options.B: Current assets (if consumed within one year)

questions.explanation: Prepaid expenses are current assets representing future economic benefits (services or goods to be received). If benefits extend beyond one year, the noncurrent portion is classified separately.
questions.tip: Prepaid = current asset (benefits within one year).

questions.question: Current assets are $250,000 and current liabilities are $150,000. What is working capital?
questions.explanation: Working capital = Current assets - Current liabilities = $250,000 - $150,000 = $100,000.
questions.tip: Working capital = CA - CL.

questions.question: Using the previous question's data, what is the current ratio?
questions.explanation: Current ratio = Current assets / Current liabilities = $250,000 / $150,000 = 1.67:1.
questions.tip: Current ratio = CA / CL.

questions.question: Discontinued operations are reported:

options.B: As a separate line item below continuing operations, net of tax

questions.explanation: Discontinued operations are presented separately after income from continuing operations, shown net of tax. This includes results of operations and any gain/loss on disposal.
questions.tip: Discontinued ops = separate section, below continuing, net of tax.

questions.question: A disposal qualifies as discontinued operations if it represents:

options.A: Any sale of an operating segment
options.B: A strategic shift that has a major effect on operations and financial results
options.C: Sale of less than 50% of segment revenue

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2014-08, a disposal must represent a strategic shift that has (or will have) a major effect on operations and financial results to qualify as discontinued operations.
questions.tip: Discontinued ops = strategic shift with major effect.

questions.question: Unusual or infrequent items are presented:

options.A: Net of tax after income from continuing operations
options.B: As a separate line within continuing operations

questions.explanation: Unusual or infrequent items are presented within continuing operations, separately disclosed. They are not shown net of tax like discontinued operations.
questions.tip: Unusual/infrequent = within continuing ops, separately disclosed.

questions.question: A multi-step income statement differs from single-step by:

options.B: Separating operating from non-operating activities and showing subtotals

questions.explanation: Multi-step format separates operating and non-operating items, shows gross profit, operating income, and other subtotals for analysis.
questions.tip: Multi-step = multiple subtotals (gross profit, operating income).

questions.question: Under US GAAP, interest paid is classified in the statement of cash flows as:

options.B: Investing activities
options.D: Either operating or financing at the entity's election

questions.explanation: Under US GAAP, interest paid is classified as operating activity. IFRS allows a choice between operating and financing.
questions.tip: GAAP: interest paid = operating; IFRS: choice.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, cash dividends paid are classified as:

options.B: Investing activities

questions.explanation: Dividends paid to shareholders are classified as financing activities because they represent a return of capital to equity investors.
questions.tip: Dividends paid = financing activity.

questions.question: When using the indirect method, an increase in accounts receivable is:

options.B: Subtracted from net income

questions.explanation: An increase in AR means sales were made but not collected. The income was earned but cash was not received, so it's subtracted from net income.
questions.tip: ↑ in current asset = subtract; ↑ in current liability = add.

questions.question: In the indirect method, depreciation expense is:

options.B: Added back to net income
options.D: Not included in the cash flow statement

questions.explanation: Depreciation is a non-cash expense that reduced net income. It's added back because no cash was spent.
questions.tip: Non-cash expenses (depreciation, amortization) = add back.

questions.question: Purchase of property, plant, and equipment is classified as:

options.B: Investing outflow

questions.explanation: Purchases of long-term productive assets are investing activities because they represent investments in the company's future operations.
questions.tip: PPE purchase = investing outflow.

questions.question: Cash received from issuing bonds is classified as:

options.B: Investing inflow

questions.explanation: Borrowing money through bond issuance is a financing activity because it represents obtaining capital from creditors.
questions.tip: Borrowing = financing inflow.

questions.question: A company acquires equipment by issuing common stock. This transaction is:

options.B: Reported in financing activities
options.C: Disclosed as a significant non-cash activity

questions.explanation: Non-cash investing and financing activities are disclosed separately (either in notes or supplemental schedule) because they don't involve cash but are significant transactions.
questions.tip: Non-cash I&F activities = supplemental disclosure.

questions.question: Sales revenue is $500,000. Beginning AR $40,000; Ending AR $55,000. What is cash collected from customers?
questions.explanation: Cash collected = Sales + Beginning AR - Ending AR = $500,000 + $40,000 - $55,000 = $485,000. (Or: Sales - Increase in AR = $500,000 - $15,000 = $485,000.)
questions.tip: Cash from customers = Sales ± change in AR.

questions.question: COGS $300,000; Beginning inventory $50,000; Ending inventory $60,000; Beginning AP $25,000; Ending AP $30,000. Cash paid to suppliers?
questions.explanation: Purchases = COGS + Ending Inv - Beginning Inv = $300,000 + $60,000 - $50,000 = $310,000. Cash paid = Purchases - Increase in AP = $310,000 - $5,000 = $305,000.
questions.tip: Cash to suppliers: find purchases, then adjust for AP change.

questions.question: The statement of changes in stockholders' equity must include:

options.B: Changes in all equity components: common stock, APIC, retained earnings, AOCI, treasury stock

questions.explanation: The statement reconciles all components of stockholders' equity from beginning to ending balances, including capital accounts, retained earnings, AOCI, and treasury stock.
questions.tip: Statement of equity: all equity components reconciled.

questions.question: The summary of significant accounting policies should disclose:

options.B: All significant accounting policies including methods, basis of consolidation, depreciation methods, etc.

questions.explanation: The accounting policies note summarizes the entity's significant policies including measurement bases, revenue recognition, depreciation methods, consolidation practices, and more.
questions.tip: First note = summary of significant accounting policies.

questions.question: Accrued expenses represent:

options.B: Expenses incurred but not yet paid

questions.explanation: Accrued expenses (accrued liabilities) are expenses incurred during the period that have not been paid. They create a liability for the unpaid amount.
questions.tip: Accrued expense = expense incurred, cash not yet paid.

questions.question: Deferred revenue (unearned revenue) is classified as:

options.B: A liability

questions.explanation: Deferred revenue is a liability because the entity has received cash but has not yet earned it. The obligation is to provide goods or services.
questions.tip: Deferred/unearned revenue = liability (obligation to perform).

questions.question: Sales $800,000; COGS $480,000; Operating expenses $200,000. What is gross profit?
questions.explanation: Gross profit = Sales - COGS = $800,000 - $480,000 = $320,000.
questions.tip: Gross profit = Revenue - COGS.

questions.question: Using the previous question, what is operating income?
questions.explanation: Operating income = Gross profit - Operating expenses = $320,000 - $200,000 = $120,000.
questions.tip: Operating income = Gross profit - Operating expenses.

questions.question: Assets and liabilities may be offset (shown net) on the balance sheet only when:

options.B: There is a legal right of offset and intent to settle net
options.C: They mature on the same date
options.D: Management chooses to present them net

questions.explanation: Offsetting requires both a legal right to set off and the intent to settle net or simultaneously. Otherwise, assets and liabilities must be shown gross.
questions.tip: Offset: legal right + intent to settle net required.

questions.question: Accumulated depreciation is presented on the balance sheet as:

options.B: A contra asset, reducing the related asset

questions.explanation: Accumulated depreciation is a contra asset that reduces the carrying value of the related fixed asset. It may be shown directly on the balance sheet or disclosed in notes.
questions.tip: Accumulated depreciation = contra asset.

questions.question: A subsequent event that provides evidence of conditions existing at the balance sheet date is:

options.B: Recognized (adjusted) in the financial statements

questions.explanation: Type I (recognized) subsequent events provide evidence of conditions at the balance sheet date and require adjustment. Type II events arise after and are only disclosed.
questions.tip: Type I (recognized) = condition existed at BS date; Type II = disclosed only.

questions.question: If the direct method is used for operating activities, what must also be provided?

options.B: A reconciliation of net income to net cash from operating activities
options.C: A forecast of next year's cash flows

questions.explanation: When using the direct method, entities must also provide a reconciliation of net income to cash from operating activities (essentially the indirect method reconciliation).
questions.tip: Direct method requires indirect reconciliation disclosure.

questions.question: Income tax expense is presented:

options.B: Separately, after income before tax
options.C: As part of cost of goods sold

questions.explanation: Income tax expense is shown as a separate line item after income before taxes, resulting in net income (or net loss).
questions.tip: Tax expense = after pretax income, before net income.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, dividends received on equity investments are classified as:

options.B: Investing activities

questions.explanation: Under US GAAP, dividends received are classified as operating activities (similar to interest received). IFRS allows choice between operating or investing.
questions.tip: GAAP: dividends received = operating.

questions.question: In the stockholders' equity section, the typical order of presentation is:

options.A: Retained earnings, Common stock, APIC, Treasury stock
options.B: Preferred stock, Common stock, APIC, Retained earnings, AOCI, Treasury stock
options.C: AOCI, Treasury stock, Common stock, Retained earnings
options.D: Common stock, Treasury stock, Preferred stock, APIC

questions.explanation: Typical order: Preferred stock, Common stock, APIC, Retained earnings, AOCI, less Treasury stock (as a contra). This presents contributed capital before earned capital.
questions.tip: Equity order: contributed capital → earned → AOCI → treasury.
